Popcorn Empire - Toy Story 4 Review: “... Toy Story 4 is a near perfect entry in one of the strongest animated franchises of all time” 9/10 Toy Story is a series of Pixar animated films that have been entertaining audiences of all ages for over 20 years. These films have consistently been on the cutting edge of animation, full of charming characters and fun stories. With each film, the stories have become more and more emotional, dealing with the existential crisis of toys and their purpose. Pushing these themes further than ever, Toy Story 4 is a near perfect entry in one of the strongest animated franchises of all time. WARNING: SPOILERS AHEAD! In this film, the story more heavily revolves around Woody than in previous entries. He still struggles to move on from Andy, and because of this he projects his loyalty onto Bonnie. When Bonnie makes Forky during her preschool orientation, Woody immediately notices how much Forky means to her. He becomes determined to a fault to keep Bonnie and Forky together. Things become complicated when Forky tries to run away during a family road trip, and Woody chases after him. When Woody gets sidetracked looking for Bo Peep, who was separated from the group years before, the rest of the gang begin to look for him and Forky. What follows is zippy adventure with fun action sequences, lots of laughs, and most importantly, a lot of heart. Many new toy characters are introduced, all of which are funny and entertaining. It’s very hard not to smile just from the sheer amount of charm in the entire cast of characters, both old and new. The humor is as goofy and hilarious as ever, especially with the new character Forky, voiced by Tony Hale. His existential nightmare causes all sorts of antics, and his childlike worldview is endearing and unique. One minor drawback is that we don’t get a lot of screen time with some classic characters such as Rex, Slinky, and Jessie. A large number of toys are left to sit in an RV for most of the movie, while Buzz and Woody run around with new characters. But this is a minor complaint when what we do get is so much fun. While the plot does rehash some ideas from previous films, what makes this story work so well is its strong emotional core. Woody learns to let go of the past, accept that his life as a child’s toy is over, and begin to pursue the life he really wants. The voice performances are top notch all around, giving this movie a lot of personality and charm. The animation is vibrant, detailed, and beautifully rendered. Overall, this is a top-of-the-line animated film, and it delivers just about everything you could want from a Toy Story sequel. 9/10

Watching Toy Story on VHS when I was a kid at elementary school was the best thing that had ever happened to me. But to have to watch the biggest, best blockbuster of the summer, Toy Story 4, is just the most wonderful thing, especially when watched twice in two weeks of June. To simply put it, Toy Story 4 has all the most wonderful equivalents of Cars 3. One reason is because it teaches about friendship and inclusion and how to love each toy the way he (and she) is. And two, among the three "Toy Stories" I've watched in the past, this one this year is the most superb, because it is reminiscent of all of them. Makes me want to relive the day I received my first toy as a little kid years ago. The lesson: sometimes it's great to remember all of the good times you had as a kid being in elementary school, other times we look forward to the present (and future). To infinity and beyond! :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :) :)

I was blown away by Toy Story 4 - amazed by the creativity and depth of the storytelling, and the brilliance of the animation. It's simply beautiful and must not be missed. You can't help but emphathize with the existential crisis of a toy - one day beloved, next day trash and start questioning your purpose of life! Brilliantly told and executed, thanks also to having a great cast of voice actors, including Tom Hanks. Seriously, WOW! Please, Disney. Start working on Toy Story 5. And make sure it's the same scriptwriters. Love them to bits.

The third Toy Story felt like the perfect send-off to the characters and franchise, however, with this new film, it feels more like an epilogue.

I enjoyed most of the film, the animation is breathtaking, almost feels real at many moments. The soundtrack by the talented Randy Newman call backs to the first two Toy Story movies, which brought back great memories of those films. 

The voice acting of the main cast like Tom Hanks, Tim Allen, Annie Potts, and Joan Cusack still sound as talented as they were in 1995. The voices brought in for the new characters like Gabby Gabby (Christina Hendricks), Forky (Tony Hale), and Duke Kaboom (Keanu Reeves) are welcome additions.

The story is easy to follow, but dramatic and somewhat deep at moments, especially to those who grew up with the franchise. Woody notices that Bonnie is unhappy, in which he helps create the arts and crafts toy, Forky. Forky tries to declare himself as trash, however, and it is up to Woody to show him his place as a toy. They then go on a road trip with Bonnie with the rest of the gang, and Woody unexpectedly reunites with Bo Peep again. This, along with other problems Woody and the other toys face over the course of the film create some great tension.

As mentioned earlier, I feel this film should be seen as more of an epilogue or extension to the events of the third film, as it focuses more on Woody, Bo, and the new characters rather than the toys we know. That doesn't mean they don't get their chance to shine in this film though. Buzz still remains as the loyal friend of Woody, and so does Jessie, but their roles seem to be pushed aside a bit, which is my only issue with the film.

This still is a great conclusion to one of Pixar's greatest series of films, and also showcases the talent that this studio still has after all these years.

This fourth installment is as good as the other two first films in the franchise, only surpassed by the third. When a new toy called "Forky" joins Woody and the gang, a road trip alongside old and new friends reveals how big the world can be for a toy. The animation was beautiful, the level of creativity in this world of living toys has no limits, the progressive new look of Bo Peep is mesmerizing and the matters of existential crisis and philosophical questions are handled cleverly. With a strong plot, a powerful ending that breaks hearts, a delightful voice cast and a ton of Pixar Easter eggs and references, this was a very enyojable time.

Toy Story 4 is a fond farewell to over 20 years of adventures with Woody and Buzz, with great new characters and even better voice acting.

The film picks up from Toy Story 3 as we find Woody feeling neglected by his new owner, Bonnie. Woody is trying to reconnect with Bonnie so he follows her to kindergarten and helps her forge a new toy named Forky. Forky wants to return to being trash, but Bonnie adores him so it won't happen on Woody's lovewatch. During Bonnie's family road trip, Forky escapes and Woody goes after him. In pursuit of Forky, he runs into old friend Bo Peep at a carnival. She has lived happily as a lost toy and offers him a new way of seeing the world. Woody questions what he wants as a toy and whether to stay with Bonnie or live with Bo. A whole new set of adventures and new friends await to point the way to Woody in this charming last installment of a long-cherished tale of toys and the children they love. 

This may be Woody's story, but Forky steals the show. Tony Hale is endearingly wacky and weird and provides a surprising amount of the film's heart. Keegan Michael Key and Jordan Peele are really well-cast as Ducky and Bunny. I can't imagine a better comedic duo bringing this pair of bickering carnival prizes to life. Key and Peele are Toy Story 4's secret weapon and the film picks up every time they're cracking jokes together. Keanu Reeves is larger than life as the small but mighty Duke Caboom, who declares himself Canada's greatest stuntman. Reeves adds a self assured confidence and lively energy that makes this character soar.

Toy Story 4 has an equally humorous and emotionally meaningful screenplay. The rapid fire pace of the jokes is balanced well with the film's bittersweet moments. We've been following Woody from the very beginning of these films and Toy Story 4 gives his arc a fitting end, while also diving deep into who he is. My only quibble with the screenplay is that, with all these new characters given so much time to shine, I miss having more time with beloved characters from earlier chapters. There's something so moving about the bond between child and toy in the way it's portrayed in this film. Forky is not your typical plaything, but what matters is the joy he brings Bonnie and the lasting impact he'll have on her life, the lasting impact all of these toys will.

I recommend Toy Story 4 for ages 5 to 18. There are doll characters that Woody and Forky meet that are somewhat creepy when introduced. These movies resonate with children who grew up with Woody and the gang and now their children can enjoy these films. If you're a Toy Story fan, you're going to adore this film. Toy Story 4 is a thoroughly entertaining, wholesome adventure and a nice way to cap off this franchise and I give it 4 out of 5 stars.

Reviewed by Benjamin P., KIDS FIRST! Film Critic. For more reviews by youth, visit kidsfirst dot org.

Toy Story 4 starts out well with a great premise, Woody is going to recover a Toy named Forky that Bonnie created using her own imagination. The ideas that were worth exploring with Forky were boundless-what is the meaning of being a toy? Toy Story 4 explores this idea for a little while and then fully abandons it halfway through the movie. It turns into the usual Toy Story plotlines. Forky is barely a part of the finale. Buzz is forced into the storyline when he really doesn't serve any purpose whatsoever (he is really forced in there to introduce two side characters and get a key, which is really something unnecessary for the story to happen). Pixar delivers a good film, which I consider Pixar's version of phoning it in. I wish they had fully explored Forky's storyline to make a great Pixar film.

Completely underwhelmed. I took my 4 yr old, who loves the first three, and he asked to leave halfway through. This hardly felt like a kids movie, despite the rating. The only jokes I laughed at were the ones aimed at adults. Most of the movie took place in an antique shop with creepy dolls, not something that kids will find interesting. They went for emotional impact, but it was recycled from previous movies & added nothing new to the franchise. The other movies had humor and child-friendly action sequences to keep kids entertained in between the emotional scenes, but this one completely missed out. Very little screen time for most of the old characters, some of the characters actually regressed (Buzz, even Woody), new characters were boring/recycled from previous films, and we had no resolution for the initial dilemma (Bonnie scared of Kindergarten). I know the point was Woody letting go, rather than about Bonnie, but it still felt completely against Woody's character to straight up leave his friends and his Kid to live a life on the road. I'm shocked the movie was reviewed so well...I'm usually in agreement with the rottentomatoes consensus, but I can't help but feel let down by this one. Even if the plot & character development was weak, I was at least hoping for an entertaining movie for my 4 yr old. Failed in all categories, except the animation was spectacular like always.

It's a law of Hollywood that sooner or later, every franchise hits diminishing returns. It's even truer with kid's movies, which typically run out of new ideas at a disheartening rate. But leave it to Pixar to buck that trend and exceed every expectation. After four movies and twenty four years, Toy story is still fresh as ever, with all the wonder and imagination of the original, coupled with hilarious new characters and compelling new themes.

If you've seen any of the trailers or posters, then you know Forky, the misshapen, neurotic new toy cobbled together from a spork and a pipe cleaner. This little fellow may be one of Pixar's best ideas in years. He's a hilariously mixed up, frightened little bundle of nerves who thinks he's literally trash. And who keeps throwing himself into the trash with a single-minded determination that only gets funnier with each of the seemingly endless repetitions.

If you think about it, this may be the first time an essentially suicidal character has been used as a running gag in a kid's movie. This will of course go completely over kids' heads. But for the rest of us, once you get past the morbidity, it's actually kind of heartwarming the lengths that Woody goes to keep Forky where he belongs. Like a veteran crisis councilor, he simply will not give up on the little guy until he realizes that he has a purpose and someone who loves him. If you think about it some more, this could honestly be used a part of a suicide prevention PSA

Although Keanu Reeves' screentime as Canadian motorcycle daredevil Duke Kaboom is briefer than the ads might suggest, it's no less awesome or outrageous. And Key and Peel are outstanding as a pair of sassy, street smart fair-prize plushies. Seriously, these guys are little psychopaths. And the new villains are seriously creep-tastic. Like cymbal clanging monkey or Bette Davis level creepy, with deeply disturbing intentions towards our heroes. Which makes the directions the movie ultimately takes them all the more amazing.

I especially loved the new Bo Peep. Not only is her role here far bigger than in past films, but's she's practically a whole new toy. Years of living on her own and caring for other cast-off toys have turned her into a formidably leader and fighter who doesn't need anyone's help, thank you very much. But for the gruff exterior and awesome kung-fu moves, she hasn't forgotten what it means to make a kid smile. This is the kind of feminist role model our kids can use.


Each of the past entries, in their own way, dealt with the fear of abandonment, whether by being replaced, wearing out, or simply becoming irrelevant as others move on. Toy Story 3 completed that arc, and brought Woody and Andy's relationship full circle. Which is why many, myself included, were surprised and even a bit wary when yet another installment was announced. It just didn't seem like there was a point in stretching out the franchise. But of course, Pixar found a way.

Moving beyond the themes of the earlier films, this installment is at heart about destiny, purpose, accepting when it's time to move on and start something new. All of these are handled with a degree of subtlety and depth which far surpasses your average kid's movie, but is exactly what we would expect from this studio. Toy Story 3 seemed like the end, and it would have made a perfectly good one. But this feels like the real closure, and the beginning of Woody's happily ever after, even as it hints at the possibility of more adventures to come. This may or may not be the end. But either way, it's another triumph for Pixar, and easily the best kid's movie of the summer.

Now, I'll talk about the movie in detail, but just the relationship part ;). First of all, I think Woody and Bo Peep's relationship started VERY late. The end of the movie, are you serious??? And to go on with that, it wasn't clear they were leaving together immediately until all the other toys left. Now, the real part is the amount of times they hugged. Like, I get that it's rated G and all, but why would you put us through the pain of watching them embrace instead of actually letting them kiss. If I'm being honest, I was disappointed with the extent that Disney/Pixar took the relationship too. Some may argue that this is because of the movie rating, but I know PLENTY of kindergartners, who had the first kiss. And I'm not talking about with their mom, I'm talking about with their Uncle ;). I'm just kidding, but for real, one small smooch from Bo on Woody's cheek couldn't of hurt, right? The second to last thing I have to say is about Forky and "Knifia??" (bear with me)'s relationship. It started at the VERY VERY end of movie. And I know, maybe you don't want to see two utensils making out, but seriously, the depth of the relationship was not thought about enough. And my theory for this is probably because the animators and directors and story writers probably work so many hours at Pixar/Disney that they don't have the time for relationships. But watch some erotica, will ya? Finally, I'd like to complain about the RUNPEE app. It told me that there was an extra after waiting for the 6 minute credits. You know what that extra was? The Pixar Intro with Duke Caboom bouncing on the I in pixar and then one tiny character walking in. Then it ended. I really expected more from this app which had such high reviews. If you're going to talk about the after-credits, make it reliable and true. But I'm not going to write a review on the app store because I know how hard that developer works. Anyway, thanks for sticking to my rant.. and I hoped this helped if your hopes were to see some erotic action in the possible conclusion to this animated saga.

 -Master Reviewer

It wasn't a bad movie. It wasn't. I think if it was something I hadn't grown up with and had Pixar not hyped it up and made it, I would have liked it more. But there just wasn't enough EMOTION. (Franchise spoilers) The first Toy Story, there was that moment when Woody told Buzz he was jealous of him and felt it should have been him strapped to a rocket. The second one had the sadness of Jessie's abandonment. The third one...oh the third one made me cry. But this one? There wasn't enough to make me FEEL. Buzz has a pretty idiotic side plot, Jessie and Andy's original toys are almost never on screen, and Woody and Bo just didn't build it up enough. I kept sitting in the theater and waiting to feel like I was experiencing this film, waiting for Pixar to hit me in the heart, and it didn't happen. Towards the end there was a part where I think I was supposed to cry and I just didn't. It wasn't built up enough. The third one was much better. This is the weakest one in the franchise. Not a horrible movie, but just not up to the standard these movies and Pixar have set.

This was a movie I was extremely skeptical of considering how well Toy Story 3 ended. The Toy Story saga is arguably Pixar’s crowning achievement in terms of an established animated franchise, and the trilogy ended perfectly. So when a 4th was announced, I was worried it might tarnish the reputation of the trilogy that came before it. What Pixar produced was another classic and possibly the most rewatch-able Toy Story movie to date. After ending Andy’s storyline and opening up this movie it has become evident that all the individual characters still have a story to tell. This movie services as that extra layer of icing on an already delicious cake. There is not nearly the same amount of story to tell as in each of the previous 3 films however. The plot of Toy Story 4 is very simple and straightforward, yet it still works in its own way. The reason it works so well is because it owns its simple story and fills the gaps with some of the funniest moments I can remember in an animated movie, as well as great character moments. The focus here is on Woody, completely closing his wonderful character arc in the best way possible. This is a movie that boasts a dynamic script and character development as opposed to an epic journey, and it’s all the better for it. The choice to do this results in a Toy Story movie that feels unique compared to the others, and is simply the result of a team of people that know exactly what they are doing and how to do it. This film was confidently crafted and achieved exactly what it wanted to and then some. Toy Story 4 concludes the franchise with a bang while standing out from the crowd. It even makes a solid case for being the best Toy Story film to date, but that would be dependent upon what the viewer loves most about these animated movies. I loved every second! 9.5/10

Toy Story 4 transforms the original Trilogy by expanding the ideas from previous films while giving another ending to the franchise. I thought 3 was the perfect ending, but now this film justifies its own existence by creating a dichotomy of expanding its own view of a toy's purpose of existence versus the toy's freedom to determine its own future. This film would make a great jumping off point for existential and teleological discussions.
My only gripe is that it somehow manages to feel smaller than previous Toy Story films in terms of narrative. It feels like a great epilogue, but I fear if they decide to make a fifth entry, this issue will become more glaring.

Toy Story 4 is a feminist rom/com—a romantic comedy in the classic mold with a feminist twist.

Indeed, the film "makes the couple" a whopping 3 times: Woody (the reluctant male who needs to be persuaded to take the plunge) and Bo Peep; Forky and (for a better word) Knifey, the "trash" twosome whose coming together as the credits roll is both unexpected and delightful, a moment of sheer cinematic bliss; and Gabby Gabby and the "lost girl."

Even though Woody is the primary protagonist, and several new male toys are introduced, "Toy Story 4" goes beyond the addition of a female toy here and there (e.g. cowgirl Jessie in "Toy Story 2"); this is the franchise's feminist film. 

Woody is fond of Bo Beep and she of him. But Bo's strengths are many and threaten to overwhelm and displace Woody's desire. She's a fiercely independent feminist, having been "on her own," beyond the security of a child's bedroom, for 7 years. She's an athlete and a warrior, using her hook as a both a weapon and climbing device. Bo and other independent toys travel around in a mechanical skunk. These "Independent Toys," which exist somewhere between "Lost Toys" and "Toys who have a Kid," are a new category for the franchise.

Duke Caboom, Ducky and Bunny are solid and funny additions to the "Toy Story" crew, but on the whole the cast is too large and dispenses with too many familiar characters to achieve the kind of focus that shaped previous editions.

These caveats aside, "Toy Story 4" is almost as good as its predecessors - and that's saying something.

‘Toy Story 4' is a lighthearted adventure that neatly wraps up the perfect character arc, which is light years better than the third, in my opinion. However, in spite of that, I'm still questing why this fourth entry exist, because everything else is paper thin.

Lets start off with the merits: I know saying the animation is amazing isn't anything new when it comes to Pixar - a company that's constantly involving with every entry. It's the same with as saying "Meryl Streep is great in...", type of situation but needs addressing ever time. I liked how beautifully polished every character and environment looked, which gave the movie a certain quality in richness. There's a scene at the beginning involving rain that's close to photo-realism and a clear growth in the animation department. I mean, the difference based on the plastic looking models back in 1995.

Perhaps my favorite character in the entire movie was Duke Caboom played by the breathtaking Keanu Reeves. Despite the little screen, Reeves manages to bring some much charisma and enjoyment to the character it was hard for me not to smile. I was surprised that a few people didn't realise it was Keanu, but then again he's casting wasn't anything secretive if you're like me that follows announcements on upcoming movies. Anywhere, I could tell Keanu was having a blast with this role and it seems very fitting considering Reeves stunt work.

I was shocked, yet glad that the character of Forky wasn't as disposable as I originally thought. Surprisingly the main message of purpose and suicide came from Forky's dilemma...no joke, well that's how I interpret it. It's something you don't pick up on, but you're brain did.

The funniest aspect of the movie came from Bunny and Ducky played by Jordan Peele and Keegan-Michael Key, especially the plan scene where the visual comedy was used effectively for laughs. I thought they were going to be so annoying based on the trailers, but I was relieved that they had some good material for the jokes and punchlines to be funny.

It's great to see the old gang back together with some welcoming new faces. Although I feel like the old gang got pushed to side characters this time around. Even Buzz didn't seem to be himself and got backtracked to do absolutely nothing through out the movie. I know there's a lot of characters and it be difficult to juggle so any, but if we've learned anything from ‘Infinity War' is that it may seem impossible until it's done.

I'll give the movie credit for not having any villains, as it would've been unneeded and a cheap trick to add dramatic tension.

However, despite the welcoming return and facing new conflict, but everything else has less to desire. I wasn't quite emotionally involved as I should've been, yet at the end, I didn't hit me as the movie intended. If I have to be honest, after seeing this a few weeks ago, I'm struggling to remember certain scenes. This movie existing is unnecessary as everything felt made up on the spot which I think is the reason why it didn't emotionally connect with me like the previous three did.

A big step down for the franchise, but family and children will enjoy it no matter what, and that ain't a bad thing.

Overall rating: "I'm trash"

Firstly I'd like to say what contributed to my ultimate decision to see this movie, besides blinding nostalgia.

A couple came into my work the day before and I noticed their son, maybe 3 years old, was holding a Toy Story coloring book. I told him it was very cool, and apparently they'd just finished watching it. The couple asked him to tell me who his favorite character was and he proceeded to yell "FORKY, FORKY". I told him I really wanna see it, and later as they were leaving the boy looked back and yelled "GO SEE TOYS, GO SEE FORKY". And so, I felt somewhat obligated!

Forky was definitely a stand out, his introduction was hilarious and his quirks as a "newborn toy" are probably the funniest bits in the movie. Followed closely by Key & Peele as Bunny & Ducky, their natural chemistry lives even in animated form and it was honestly a really refreshing change of pace for Toy Story. Another highlight was Keanu Reeves as Duke Kaboom, "Canada's Greatest Stuntman", he's not in the movie as much as I expected him to be but when he was he pretty much stole the scene every time. I would argue this is probably the funniest of all 4 movies, everyone gets a chance to shine and there are some fun running gags.

However, the introduction of new characters comes with the sidelining of familiar faces. Rex, Ham, the Potato Heads (with archived lines from the late Don Rickles), Jesse and so on are present and ready, but they're restricted to one liners and emotional support. Even the ones introduced in Toy Story 3 don't have much to do. It's definitely up to Woody, Buzz and Bo Peep carry the load, and carry it they do. Bo Peep, a character meant to be the flirt for Woody in Toy Story 1&2, is now a battle damaged warrior who kicks ass! Her story as a lost toy is one of the most interesting parts and it really surprised me just how much emotional baggage she was given. Unfortunately Buzz doens't have much to do, he has a running gag throughout the movie that got some laughs outta me but what they did to make it work kinda took me out of it sometimes. I guess any sort of character development ended with Toy Story 2. Having said that it was really good to hear Tim Allen back and he hasn't skipped a beat as Buzz Lightyear. The central villain character is a toy named Gabby Gabby, and I was afraid of having another toy villain because every villain after Toy Story 1 has been a toy and they've never been as good as Sid. That's still very much the case, but Gabby Gabby is really the best of the toy villains! She has interesting motivations and you can actually sypathize with her.

But Toy Story has not at all forgotten who the main character is. Woody remains the core of this series, and somehow 4 movies in and 24 years later he continues to grow as a character. His arc is wisely set up from the very beginning of the movie and the themes related to him are really the driving force. And these themes come with some unexpectedly emotional moments, perhaps even more so Toy Story 3. That's right, get ready to tear up my fellow manchildren.

Anyway, I really liked this movie. Better than I expected and definitely more ambitious than Tory Story 3. And the animation, my god, who sold their soul to make it look that good? I'm almost certain they filmed in actual places for certain parts, it's nuts.

Mistake. Most of this movie was a mistake. I am only giving it a half of a star because the animation was sleek and clean. But the plot, oh god the plot was a piece of garbage. It is clearly established over the other three movies that the toy gang is tight. It is the entire PREMISE of these movies in fact. But of course, the lovey dovey romance of Bo Peep and Woody had to ruin it. It was unbelievable. In the first movie, yes, he liked her, and the sexual tension was clear, but there was no way he would jeopardize the relationship of his air tight group and Andy over it. And then, in the second movie, he has some tension with Jesse. This was actually nice, because it helped give Woody a reason to be conflicted over wanting to leave his group, or be put and honored in a museum. But nope. The tension of that movie did not follow through whatsoever. Toy story 3 was the best movie by far, because it had an amazing script that left me crying, and two THERE WAS NO ROMANCE. (I do not count the romance between Jesse and Buzz because it didn't directly influence the plot). But of course, all good things must come to an end. And I was convinced that the ending in Toy Story 3 was the finale, which was a good one to be honest. But of course, the franchise wanted more money. They ended up changing the characters just in the pursuit of more moolah. In Toy Story 4, most of the group, all of the wacky and mischievous characters that complimented each other end up sitting in a van for all of the movie. It was heart wrenching. Not cool, Pixar. And trying to scare all of the young impressionable children in the audience? That was awful! And the characters, Jesus, the characters! There are so many I barely remember their names! I pretty much only remember the gang! They are only used when the plot needs them! Or for shabby comedic effect. Like that whole minute of Lame Canadian where he poses. Overall, this movie was a disappointment. I'm only a freshman in high school. I've grown up on this franchise and I've always been a fan. Until now. Woody would never leave the gang. Never. I'm highly offended that this movie made it past the test viewers. I'm utterly horrified and shocked.

Sincerely,
A disappointed 14 year old fan.

This movie is a solid addition to the franchise. Pixar is back in true form to deliver a fun, meaningful film to warm audience hearts around the world. It's less tear-jerking than previous entries, but it still weaves the Pixar signature great, meaningful narrative that bucks storytelling standard. There are some small but significant character deviations for Buzz and Bo Peep, and not always in a good way. But apart from some mostly harmless missteps it is the sequel fans hoped they could make and feared they wouldn't be able to pull off. Most people probably knew they were going to watch it before reading this, but if you were on the fence, definitely go see it.

Closest comparison: It's like a fresh Toy Story 3 with some of the logistical problems of Finding Dory and a touch of sequelitis.

Toy Story 4 is an enjoyable film, but for every fun moment it seemed that there was an equally frustrating one. The new characters that were introduced didn't seem forced and brought something new to the franchise, but most of the characters we have come to love were left behind. I would like to have seen Buzz and Jessie play a larger role in the film, but it seems like they were both limited to just a few scenes in favor of Woody and Bo Peep having the max amount of screen time. Even Forky, the central plot point of the film, didn't get enough screen time, so we could see Bo Peep and Woody's relationship be fleshed out on screen. I did love every second of Duck & Bunny's screen time. I laughed every time they were on screen and their characters definitely brought something new to the Toy Story Universe. Overall, I enjoyed the movie, but it wasn't what I wanted in a new Toy Story, but I am a 28 year old man looking at the film through nostalgia glasses. I am sure the movie would be greatly appreciated by the target audience.

The Pixar films rarely disappoint, and Toy Story 4 is no exception. I like that we got to revisit what happened to Bo Peep — and I found the evolution of her character to be intriguing. For me, it really brought the Toy Story franchise full circle — in the first film, Woody is terrified at the prospect of being a lost toy, but in this movie, Bo and some of the others fully embrace it. I thought there were some really funny moments in this movie. It had a lot of heart. They could have ended the Toy Story franchise with Toy Story 3 and that masterful ending. But I’m okay with Pixar making this one.

Once again, I feel like everyone on Rotten Tomatoes saw a different movie than I did. This was a huge disappointment. The plot was a mess, there were too many characters and they were mostly flat and just band-aids when the filmmakers couldn't decide what to do next. The first three films of this series were pinnacles of entertainment and resonance. What happened? And why do the critics love this swampy disaster? I'm mystified and felt like I had to inject some truth into this morass of fake love for a faulty product. Avoid this thing, even on streaming!

"Toy Store 4" is the sequel that works, even after three films, even lower than its others, precisely because of the dramatic and sentimental concept, the fourth quarter of the pixar is cold, but with characters hot, but the sensation of filer film is only saved in its final act, which gives a much better charge to what was being sent.

The script has highs and lows in all respects, the creation of new, and good characters, who work very well, the strengthening and growth of Betty, who creates a strong and powerful Golden, naturally and legitimately without seeming forced, creating a different character, however, the various other great characters of the franchise end up being left behind here, like Jessie Or Mr. Potato. the diminution of the screen time of the character of the buzz lightyear implies in a protagonism, still more evident of the Woody, who is a good personage, and here carries much of the dramatic responsibility. Gaby Gaby is a good character with a very interesting bow, but with a common ending, "Garfinho" brings a new symbolism to the franchise and works well, even having a more comical function and serving as the script key.

Toy Story has always been remembered for having a spectacular animation, this is its first, and in its fourth version, clearly a new level is achieved, the film has a spectacular animation with light and shadow games, no mechanization, fluid movements and real, in terms of animation and direction, Toy Story 4 is spectacular.

Toy Srory 4 has few artifices for the children's audience, one or another joke and the visual issue, the rest is a film that little children will have fun with a load and more adult concept, the film has a message on maturation, attachment, love and of course, friendship. Toy Story 4 only stands above its predecessors in terms of animation, however, it still continues a good movie.

A rare movie where the emotions it tries to evoke justifies the action , with the animation which makes for a phenomenal movie despite its simpleness . Like all Toy Story movies , it re - emphasizes Woody need to be needed but places him as a father figure who indirectly created Forky , and having a rekindled experienced with Bo Peep which acts as his guide throughout . Add in how there is no blatant antagonist brings the progression towards modern society where things are on a spectrum and towards Woody existential crisis with the perfect end towards the franchise . Also with the other characters and their stories make for many interesting encounters along the way .

A spectacular "conclusion" (who knows with Disney) to the Toy Story franchise, this 4th installment is another beautiful masterpiece made from the Pixar gang that doesn't disappoint when held up to its previous films. Clever, funny, and at times down right emotional, the film will have both adults (who were probably kids when the first film came out) and children fully engaged in the story, cheering on their favorite toys and hoping for another 4 movies. Over the course of 24 years, Disney has shown us there is much more to toys then just being "a child's play thing," it's shown that no matter where life takes you, never forget that "you've got a friend in me."

Excellent addition to the Toy Story franchise! All our favorites were represented and we even got a nostalgic visit from Andy (via flashback). Loved the plot too! Fitting and fulfilling to see Woody, who has loyally and steadfastly spent the entirety of the last 20 years looking out for his kid and all his friends, finally reach the point in his, er, life where he makes a decision about what is best for him and his happiness! Had to have been at least 4 scenes in the last 20 minutes that could jerk a tear from darn near anyone with a pulse. This felt very final (I know we all felt that way about Toy Story 3 though), but at last in that ending our main characters were all still together so continuing the story with the right idea could work. Now it feels FINAL. I know money carries the day on Hollywood, but I hope the powers that be let the sorry rest now...if so, awesome, Dare I say, perfect finale!

Toy Story 4 — Finally saw this movie (about time!). It was really good (Big surprise there *sarcasm*). I was reminded immediately how much I love these characters and this series. The animation in this movie was incredible. The details they put into every little thing is amazing. Just when you think the animation couldn’t get any better, they go ahead and one-up themselves going further and further into the details of everything. This movie was definitely more centered around Woody and BoPeep (and Forky) than any others, which I was fine with, but did have me missing not seeing the other characters quite as much. There were a couple scenes toward the end that got me a little bit teary-eyed, but I still think nothing tops the end of Toy Story 3. That being said, I really enjoyed this movie and think it was a good addition to the series. They could’ve called it quits after Toy Story 3 and I would’ve been happy, but Pixar knows how to handle this series and these characters and  put together a great movie. Toy Story 3 is still my favorite of the series, but Toy Story 4 was really entertaining and addressed some newer themes that kept things feeling fresh and engaging. Go see it if you haven’t! :)

My Childhood is complete. Toy Story has been in my heart for a very long time! I was born to love the Toy Story franchise! Woody has always been my favorite deputy for as long as I can remember! And this story is all about the cowboy. It broke me with tons of emotional scenes and heart breaking decisions! I love the new characters they put in this movie too! Ducky and Bunny, Duke Caboom, and Forky! Why I said emotional and heart breaking is because Woody has always been loyal and watching my character grow over the years to now in Toy Story 4 (2019) It was hard for me to watch him make some sacrificing decisions. So this move I'd give it not 5 stars not even 10 stars! I give it 1,000 stars! Such a great film, and definitely worth the money! GO SEE THIS MOVIE!!!  I'm disappointed for the score on this website. I was incredibly disappointed with this film. This film may have single highhandedly annihilated the entire "Toy Story" franchise. This movie had more problems than it had main characters (which is a problem within itself). 

First of all, Buzz Lightyear (my personal favorite toy) was completely clocked by the main story-line. For a charter that was featured so heavily in the first three movies, I was incredibly upset that he seemed to only be a supporting charter. This is just the beginning. 

Secondly, toys are NOT made to interact with humans - periodt. Buzz Lightyear (my personal favorite toy) spoke to a human as he was being flinged into the cabinet like Forky tried to fling himself in the trash can (which happened far too many times). 

Third, on the subject of Forky, WHY IN THE WORLD is he not called Sporky? He is clearly a spork - as stated many times in the film. Obviously this was a clear oversight of the writers. 

Fourth, the ventriloquist dolls featured in the film are very frightening - even more so than the Lot's-O'-Huggin' Bear from Toy Story 3. I had a very young boy sitting next to me during the showing, and he jumped and was severely frightened each time they appeared.

Firth of all, Gabby Gabby did not deserve Woody's help. She stole his voice box! I was incredibly disappointed that Gabby Gabby has not thrown in the trash to be compounded. Woody lost his voice box, and it was forgotten by the rest of the toys! This lack of realism is why the Toy Story franchise is failing. 

And lastly, Woody should not been the only toy to abandon the pack. Woody and Buzz have been together since the first movie, and it was cruel to split them up over another toy. I was deeply saddened by this creative decision from the writers.

Toy Story 4 truly hits home as the fourth addition to the series. It certainly does not lack in good humor, and the evolution of Woody's life as a toy really shines. His undying loyalty and sacrifice for the good of whatever kid owns him is a heartwarming spectacle on screen. The new characters are interesting and full of life. They all feel like they fit perfectly into the plot of the movie and are not just an excuse to sell more toys to kids. Keanu Reeves' steals the show with his character, Duke Caboom. Each line he delivers is gold and guarantees a solid laugh from the audience. If you're looking for a masterpiece with heart-tugging emotion, quality jokes, and a different take on the world of these toys, this film is for you.

Toy Story was a perfect trilogy in a world where cinematic threepeats often fail (think Matrix, Pirates, Spider-Man, and the most dreaded of all, Godfather III). Toy Story was about why we love our possessions. Toy Story 2 was about why our possessions love us. And the now penultimate Toy Story 3 capped it off clean with why we eventually have to part with our possessions. So the questions us film purists had when Pixar announced a fourth entry were: What's left? Artistic merit or cash cow? Why toy with a perfect set? If third movies are bad, fourths usually get the reboot, or take off in a different direction, frequently getting lost. Part 4 was particularly unkind to Indiana Jones, whose perfect trilogy long stood as a cinematic staple, until crystal skulled aliens transported the archaeologist to an awkward dimension. It's that whole can't leave a good thing alone business. Scream took the meta approach, making jokes about how fourth movies function in a franchise. I'm happy to report Toy Story 4 was also self-aware, if only a little less poignant. 

Toy Story 4 outright admits to themes of throwing itself in the garbage and having nothing left to do, roles played by Forky (Tony Hale) and Woody (Tom Hanks) respectively. Woody learned some time ago that the only important role he had as a toy was to love his kid to the fullest, to be willing to do anything for them. He soon realizes Bonnie (Madeleine McGraw) is no longer interested in playing with him, an awfully contrived plot device since he was just recently her favorite toy, and she still plays with the others. 

Bonnie is terrified to start kindergarten orientation, and Woody wants to help. He shows up at school with her and assembles some trash for arts and crafts, in which she concocts the now infamous Forky, our first born-anew handcrafted toy. There's a moment of consciousness-awareness that's both frightening and hilarious, reminding us of clones or replicants awakening in sci-fi films. Bonnie loves Forky, but Forky hates his existence, feeling bound to the trash from whence he came. Woody has to convince him that life is worth living, but Forky's persistence winds them both on the street as lost toys. Nothing new to the formula, the toys set out to accomplish one smaller task and wind up far away, homeward bound. So what's fresh?

Toys, a whole lot of them, so much that most of the former cast is reduced to small appearances or cameos. Key & Peele reunite as Ducky & Bunny, carnival toys stuck to each other and a shooting gallery wall with little hope of ever having a kid, until Buzz Lightyear (Tim Allen) intervenes. Officer Giggle McDimple's (Ally Maki) is one of those even the smallest can make a difference characters, Bo Peep's sidekick. Perhaps the most anticipated comes from the voice of America's favorite urban legend, Keanu Reeves as the fitting stuntman Duke Kaboom, yet another abandoned toy driven by anguish. And a softer, more sympathetic antagonist riles things up as our heroes try to get home, Gabby Gabby (Christina Hendricks), accompanied by her creepy henchmen, the Dummies.

There's a lot of fun and spectacle, but for the caliber franchise that Toy Story has been, was it necessary? At times, it does seem to be on repeat, upping the ante to the third's ‘say goodbye' tear-jerking – "higher on the strings, Randy [Newman]." Has Pixar found a comfortable, safe formula that we're just easily susceptible to? I'm not sure I can identify the bold, overarching point, which each of the others have, nor any evolution, besides technology, with incredible texture/motion animation in the carnival at night, and a photorealistic cat. The flashback to losing Bo Peep (Annie Potts) is hardly an impactful starting point, although her re-emergence into the story, as a toy-wielding camper glides Bo and Woody right into each other, was magical. Still, it seems this film is made mostly to get Woody and Bo back together, which would've made for a better TV short film.

There's some confusion as to where our sympathies should lie. Woody and Bo are in dispute over who's really ‘lost.' Gabby is too cruel to be so easily forgiven. Bonnie's despair over losing Forky gets annoying. Whatever sympathy we lose for her is traded for dad (Jay Hernandez), who's having a Clark Griswold experience, one failure after the other on a family road trip. And while some of the humor works, some overstays it's welcome, particularly Forky's garbage montage, making it's point about his destiny redundant.

We've been told Toy Story 4 will be the end, but I'm not convinced. I was taught a five-act structure in school, and this easily feels like act IV, the false resolution. It's probably more wishful thinking, as the voice actors aren't getting any younger; we already bade farewell to the late Don Rickles (Mr. Potato Head) for this round. But I think fans are owed a more satisfying ending than this ‘going rogue' business, which I'll not elaborate on. There's no shortage of fun and laughter, and it's ultimately worth seeing. But by Toy Story standards, it's a bit like going from a Buzz Lightyear multi-feature space ranger action figure to an old, worn, pull-string Woody doll. And yet we still love that cowboy, so it's got a friend in us.

Heartfelt, funny and gorgeously animated, "Toy Story 4" is a thrilling final chapter in the beloved animated series. Packed with plenty of colourful characters, hilarious laughs and terrific performances from an A-list cast, the film delivers everything that fans could have hoped for. At a first glance, extending the series may have seemed like an impossible feat. However, director Josh Cooley has pulled it off seamlessly. Not only does "Toy Story 4" bring back the beloved toys we've grown to adore, but it also introduces fresh faces into the cast. Forky, for instance, is the funniest character and a standout in the new additions to the cast. Although "Toy Story 4" offers fun family entertainment, it is not a film without flaws. At times, it feels slightly rushed and doesn't give all the characters a chance to shine. Due to its rushed pacing, it isn't quite on par with its predecessors in terms of quality. Nevertheless, fans of the franchise will definitely enjoy "Toy Story 4" and so will movie-goers seeking family-friendly entertainment this summer season. If this truly is the last time we see Woody and his friends on the big-screen, its a fitting farewell to the toys we've grown to love and adore.
What else can I say, the end crowns the work. It was marvelous journey to the childhood, that I won't forget for long.

"To infancy and beyond!"

How attached are you to Andy and his Toys, Woody, Buzz and the gang? Don't bother answering because, like me, I already know just how dependent you are on these peerless Pixar characters. Chances are you've grown up with these movies...

...Having watched Toy Story 4, I further suggest that these movies have grown up with you! And they have just earned a First Class Honours Degree. Forget going to college with Andy  - this incomparable quadrilogy provides the most nuanced examination of Attachment Theory imaginable. 

Attachment, in psychology, refers to the special bond and the lasting relationships that children form with one or more adults.  

Underlying the truly genius Toy Story saga is an in-depth cognitive, psycho-dynamic and socio-psychological exploration, of the theory of Attachment.

The saga initially tackles Attachment Parenting during the childhood years, involving all the ways parents must hold a child close for reliance on a secure dependence to be established. We can view Woody as a substitute child dependent on the love and attention of his primary carer, Andy. But we can just as easily see Woody as the carer, with Andy dependent on the safe love provided to him by his trusty toy. Take your pick; it works both ways, just as the films work harmoniously as entertaining flicks for kids and detailed studies of the Attachment Theory.

Don't believe me? Well ok then, push the button, spread the wings and watch my theory fly...
...or at the very least fall with style:

Toy Story 

As with babies, we learn from Woody that toys have a kind of biological drive to seek proximity to a primary carer (or a child to play with them) for survival and fulfilment. Woody et al are dependent on the physical and emotional availability of Andy to play with them. We see that the toys' relationships with their child owners are crucial to their trust of others, their understanding of relationships generally and their feelings about themselves. Just check out the juxtaposition between Andy's contented toy box with the tragically nervous and dysfunctional behaviour of Sid's mistreated and mutated playthings! The drive in Woody for closeness to Andy promotes attachment behaviours, which helps him feel safe and wanted. Woody's development of attachment relationships continues as he gradually learns to think about others' feelings, manage relationships with his peers and co-operate with others, not least the insufferable new addition to the family, Buzz Lightyear!

Synchronous with the above theme, Andy himself - throughout the first movie - is dependent on his toys, not least his trusty old chum Woody. His attachment to Woody is self evident - the cuddly gunslinger equivalent of a comfort blanket.

Toy Story 2

In the sequel, Woody is no longer the selfish and dependent infant. He is growing into adolescence, and in so doing is learning more about self. As an adolescent who has benefitted from regular love, affection and ‘favourite toy' status from Andy, our maturing cowboy is reassured enough by Attachment to begin flirting with autonomy - more individual responsibility, more expression of individuality and a yearning to direct and lead his own life. Of course he is not quite ready to cut loose, and dutifully, nay triumphantly, returns to the safe haven of his room with Andy... 

...albeit he is no longer the vulnerable and defenceless old rag tag cowboy we had seen in the first film but rather a self assured collectible leader of the Round Up Gang! 

Meanwhile, in the second instalment of the saga, Andy is growing into adolescence himself. No longer quite so dependent on his toys, he even briefly casts Woody aside, daring to travel to camp without his old ally. For Heaven's sake, the bewildered cowboy even finds himself gathering dust on the shelf! Woody feels like any parent who suddenly realises his child would prefer to go to the pictures with his friend instead of his mum and dad. Like Woody though, he can't stay away for long just yet, and runs giddily back into the protective safety of his beloved Sheriff. Attachment runs deep don't you know!

The latter two entries then move seamlessly yet suddenly into an exploration of Detachment Parenting during the adolescent years, involving all the ways parents must let the child go for a confident independence to grow.

Toy Story 3

Woody has proven very good at becoming an integral part of Andy's life, and vice versa, Great, I hear you all proclaim. After all, close parental attachment nurtures a founding sense of interpersonal trust and a solid platform for the development that follows.

However, it's not all rosy in the garden. Highly attached parents of children (or toys) can have a devil of a time not excessively holding on, hovering over and helping out when the time for more parental detachment arrives. 

But time waits for no-one - not even a digitally created cowboy doll! Without adequate parental detachment, developing individuality for identity and responsibility for independence are very difficult to accomplish. 

Letting go - I know, I'm already welling up thinking about the scene - is done through parental permission and acceptance. Both Woody and Andy - whether you view either or both as the maturing child or the heartbroken parent - converge to permit and accept a final parting of the ways. Detachment can be THE most painful process. Parents have to let go some life agenda they had for the child, "We determine the direction you take;" to "We accept that you must set your own course through life." - "THANKS GUYS"! 😭

Toy Story 4

For Woody, just as for any child or indeed parent, detachment can be an emotionally costly process. He has now let go of Andy, who is no longer his to control or his to rely upon. 

In infancy and childhood, through attachment, the child trusts in dependence on the parent, but in adolescence, through parental detachment, the child learns to trust in dependence on self. Woody, as you view him a grown child who has flown the nest, is no longer tied to a carer. He can make his own choices; choose his own path; take his own fork in the road!

But what about Woody the primary carer? Parental detachment to foster independence is neither an expression of parental desertion nor abandonment of parental love. While daring to let go of Andy, and then ultimately Bonnie, Woody still holds fast to his commitment of continuing to care. He will, as Forky wisely observes, never get over Andy. And he requires the assurance of Buzz that "She'll be ok, Bonnie will be ok", before he gives his final permission and acceptance to cut loose with Bo Peep! 

Whether the parent or the older adolescent, Woody must pay a price of this new independence; he must, like Bo Peep already has, learn to live with the new challenges independent of his prior attachment - Decide for myself; Define myself; Direct myself. "To infancy...and beyond"!

We all thought exactly the same thing when Pixar announced they were going to makeToy Story 4, What?! The third film ended the series perfectly. However after seeing Toy Story 4 I have to say I am very impressed and surprised. I really liked this film. It is definitely the weakest of the Quadrilogy for me, however that doesn't say all that much as all the movies are so good. Pixar have done it again. They have put in so much care, effort and time into this. It's been 9 years since the 3rd film so there was a lot of expectation. This is a funny, moving, charming film which is a great extension of Toy Story 3's ending assuming this is the last one. The ending is satisfying, it's not super dark and intense like the incinerator from part 3 but it leaves you feeling warm. The new characters are all awesome, especially Gabby Gabby. Her character arc was very emotional, we think at first she is the antagonist however that is since revealed not to be true. I also think Duke Caboom, Ducky and Bunny are all hilarious.This is also a greta ending for Woody and I feel like Woody's character has really come full circle and has matured. Its great seeing Bo back and rekindling her relationship with Woody and seeing how her character has changed. The music is classic Toy Story and it works. It moves at a great pace. Its a wonderfully surprising return to these characters but the only criticism I have is that a lot of the original characters don't get a lot to do, which is a slight shame but other than that, well done Pixar! :) This movie was unnecessary but I am glad you made it. But now is a good place to stop. The Toy Story films have been consistently fantastic and the 4 movies work and I really feel this film is the official ending of the Toy Story saga and it should stay that way. I would score this film a 9/10

Toy Story 4 is a generally enjoyable film, made better by the incredible animation that Pixar delivers. The lighting and shadows darting across Bo-Peep's facial features are a level of detail that can easily be taken for granted and it is fun to watch just to appreciate the spectacle and feat of CGI. 

That said, though, it was a little questionable at first as to whether this film was needed. Nobody was really asking for Toy Story number 4 . When the news was announced that Disney and Pixar were doing it I remember wondering why, what story was left to tell? We had concluded the tale, Toy Story 3 was a beautiful end to an animated saga that had carried a generation through childhood into adolescence, and now they were creating a fourth? Could we, as an audience that had departed this train and exited the platform be bothered to get back on board? I mean, where was it even headed? We all know how this goes, Disney did it with Pirates of the Caribbean, a new trilogy of films that can't live up to the originals and succeed only in tainting the franchise.

I was pleasantly surprised though to find myself exiting the cinema, having watched the most recent installment, with a sense of closure that I didn't even realise I needed.

I mean think about it this way. The end of Toy Story 3 left Woody nodding a solemn farewell to Andy, about to jump into a new life with Bonnie, the adorable and excitable kindergartener who could help these toys continue fulfilling their purpose as children's playthings. It was a bittersweet end, we connected with Andy as he clung on desperately to the remnants of childhood, but were happy to see another child find joy in playing with the characters that we'd grown to love through 3 incredible movies. 

But nobody was asking, yet probably should have been, what happens in 6 or 7 years time when Bonnie is too old to play with these toys? Are we going to have to pick up the story again and watch them all find a new home? And what about Bo-Peep? Where the heck is she? And what even defines a toy? Why are other seemingly inanimate objects in this franchise not sentient, and what happens if something that was not previously labelled a toy is suddenly redefined as one by a child playing with it?  

Toy Story 4, often horrifyingly, addresses all of these unanswered questions, and delivers a hilarious, emotional punch that nobody knew they needed. We are introduced to Forky, an agonised creation made from trash that suffers an existential crisis of identity whilst being, literally, talked down from the ledge by Woody. Somehow Disney turn this into a storyline that lasts 100 minutes, and though it felt more like the tying of several ends that I wasn't aware were even loose until they were picked up in this movie, it was nonetheless enjoyable to watch and entertaining throughout. Let us not forget, this is a kids film, and the giggles and laughter echoing through the screening are testament to the fact that this delivers to it's target audience. 

Will Toy Story 5 happen? Knowing Disney - yes. Should it? Probably not.

Astounding animation and overall a good plot. I did like it better than the third movie overall, but I felt it was an unnecessary addition to the franchise and destroys all the messages of the previous movies. 
(Spoilers ahead...)
My main issues were as follows:
Firstly it makes no sense to me that Bonnie would play with every toy except Woody, especially after she seemed so interested in playing with him in the third movie. Secondly, the whole voice box thing rubbed me the wrong way how Gabbie Gabbie blackmailed him to get it and not only kept it bu the end of the movie but also got a happy ending... it just kinda felt very off to me. I think it wouldve been more powerful if shed found a kid without needing the voice box... sends a better message of not needing to fix yourself to find a friend. That goes against the message of the precious movies, especially the second where theyd always say Andy will love you no matter what and Woody dealt with his arm being ripped and Andy still wanting to play with him regardless. Lastly, the idea Woody would just leave the entire gang of toys for Bo seems a bit out of character. And goes against the main theme of the other three films. Overall, I did like the movie due to the sheer amazement I had watching Pixars animation quality progress and come such a long way, but story wise it felt more like a fanfiction than something true to what gave Toy Story its heart in the first place and so fell flat.

The plot was shallow and not well thought out.  The storyline between Bopeep and Woody being a thing never happened.  For them to go off into the sunset together, first you have to develop the love story.  How do toys fall in love? Date? Where was the moment where they both knew they were in love?  There was no first kiss.  There was potential there to develop a great storyline, but the creative genius must've fizzled out. It seemed shallow on so many levels. I thought the movie took a turn for the worse (from 5 stars down to 4) when the story became too much about the toys, and less of the cute interaction between the toys and the humans. Then, it became downright creepy when (spoiler alert) the doll Gabby went psycho on Woody, having her mannequin "goons" on woody to basically harvest his organs (voice box) for her own selfish enterprise. Really, I don't know if other adults picked up on this even though I'm sure the kids didn't. I honestly could not decide if Gabby was supposed to be a villain in this plot, yet the story was told as though she were a sympathetic character. Maybe I'm overthinking this. I think for the kiddos, still a great flick. For the adults, maybe a good opportunity for a restroom break halfway through.

This is undoubtedly the very best of the four movies. Think of what a space shuttle is in comparison to an ox cart. That's how far Toy Story 1 and 4 are apart. While the first one was surely groundbreaking in the way that it was the very first movie completely produced on PCs, this latest edition is a pure work of art. Even the third one was undeniably an animation with quite clear cartoon characteristics. But the fourth one goes actually "To infinity and beyond", and really far beyond. Not only the toy characters look real and alive, but everything in the surrounding looks real as well. From a car to a Ferries Wheel, from a simple can to a complete antique shop. It's absolutely unbelievable. Judging from the laughter inside the cinema everybody obviously had a great time (only adults) as the movie isn't only way more advanced technologically, but it's also sweeter, funnier and wittier. 8/10 points.

I REALLY wanted to like this movie. Toy Story 3 wrapped the story lines up so well that it would seem there wasn’t a need for another sequel. However, I was still excited to see this one. The movie started off very promising as they did a recap of Woody and the gang as they transitioned from Andy to Bonnie. Moving forward to Bonnie’s first day at kindergarten where Woody was there for her was really touching. Then we started the story about Forky and things started going downhill. Forky as a toy character was cute and funny but the story fell off the tracks when Woody went on his quest to find Bo Peep. Bo Peep was a minor character in the Toy Story saga so to see this character take over the movie was disappointing. Suddenly Woody is almost useless and Buzz becomes a blithering idiot. This is totally out of character for Woody, Buzz, and Bo Peep. The rest of the gang we love so much was barely in the movie. Bullseye isn’t in it at all. The story would have been much better had Jessie been Woody’s partner in finding Forky and Bo Peep. However, Jessie was just an accessory in the background here. It was jolting to watch Woody become so useless when he had always been so clever and resourceful in the other films. Even more insulting was expecting the audience to accept a brain dead and cowardly Buzz Lightyear. Why did the writers do this? Finally, the ending was a real clunker. Woody would NEVER abandon his friends like he did here. He would NEVER give up on his “kid” even if he was no longer her favorite toy. It all just felt so wrong. I kept waiting for the tears to well up but this ending was not emotional at all. So was the movie really awful? No, it wasn’t. Did it at least live up to the other three films in the series? Not even remotely! Despite trying my very best to love this film it just didn’t work for me. What a shame.

( Warning, Toy Story 4 spoilers ahead. ) 

Toy Story was my childhood. I grew up watching reruns of the earlier Toy Story movies, and the ending for the third movie was very satisfying to me. Until I watched the fourth installment, and I fell in love with the whole franchise again. 

I thoroughly enjoyed this film from beginning to end -- I was a mix of emotions. Props to Pixar for creating Gabby Gabby, a villain that actually has character to her. Someone that you can sympathize with, and understand why she acted the way she did. I also really liked the newer characters. They're all very diverse. 

Cons, is the heavily lack of screen time for the original characters. I barely noticed the older classics like Hamm, Mr potato head, Bullseye the first time I watched the movie. Even Jessie didn't have much of a spotlight. 

All in all, I really like the fourth installment. And honestly, i'm secretly hoping for a fifth in the next decade or so. I usually don't enjoy films or shows that have more than two or three parts to them, but Toy Story 4 was really, really good. 

And even if a Fifth movie isn't coming anytime soon, i'd love more shorter films like The Toy Story of Terror, Hawaiian Vacation and more. Hopefully showcasing how Buzz and the gang has been doing, or how Woody has been holding up at the carnival.

At my daughter's request we saw this in the theater the day after her seventh birthday.   There are some really interesting parts to it – the Forky the spork, for example, who doesn't want to be a toy and has a "death drive" of throwing himself into the trash; and conversely, the doll Gabby, who feels she can only be a complete toy with a working voicebox, and is willing to hurt others (in particular, Woody) to acquire one.  Toy Story 4 probably features the least interaction with humans, and specifically families, of the entire series, a gap which is partly filled by Woody, who tries to parent Forky, and Bo Peep, who looks after her sheep and other "independent" toys.  And in the end, both choose a life together, away from humans, after helping Gabby find a girl for her.  Is this what it looks like when toys grow up themselves, or is it more like retirement?   While neither kiddo is especially into dolls or action figures, this series still retains its charm for them, I think because it captures the mystery of childhood play.  And that can sometimes be violent and unjust, as demonstrated by this film.

An unfortunate installment of what should have only been a trilogy. Bo peep suddenly changed to a different texture. Buzz had hardly any lines. And almost non of the beloved characters were at the forefront of the film. 
Also as a children's (and children at heart's  film) I found the movie to be a bit off-putting for small children. Between the creepy menacing marionettes and the creepy extra cut scene at the end with the giant attacking laser eyed stuff animals attacking people, I didn't feel comfortable with my three year old watching. For that matter my Toy Story obsessed toddler didn't find any interest in the film. 
Buzz seemed to revert back to OG Buzz who knew nothing about being a toy despite the fact that he's been a toy for more than 6 years.

At this point everyone knows what Pixar is… THE ANIMATION GOAT. They have been just putting out banger after banger for years and they do not seem to be stopping any time soon.

Toy Story however has always been their most prized franchise. It is the film that started it all, and it is easily the most popular franchise of any that Pixar has put out. To be honest 3 is so perfect and heartwarming that it felt like the perfect end of the franchise. When people heard this was happening, and saw the first trailer, there was many reservations heading into this.

Never in doubt though Pixar still brings the heat, especially with the Toys. This story is about how the toys new owner Bonnie makes a new friend Forky, and he decides to get lost in the forest. Woody goes after him because he is just so noble, and winds up on the adventure of a lifetime. Any more and I would kinda be spoiling so lets just get to the grades and we will finalize another fantastic entrant to the Pixar canon.

Animation – A It is Pixar and they always do it right. There were some legitimately incredible shots that could have been in live action movies, particularly one where Woody and Forky are walking down a highway. They also managed to make a spork look normal and fit into the universe which is an achievement in itself.

Voice Cast – A+ All the big dogs are back, Hanks, Allen, Cusack, Ratzenberger, and all the old pals. However, we get four all time performances from new characters: Key and Peele as two bears that kids try to win at the carnival, Ally Maki as a toy cop, and Keanu Reeves (in the midst of a Keanuassaince) dominating the screen as a toy daredevil. It really does not get better than this as far as voices.

Music – B The score was typically very good, and they brought back You've Got a Friend in Me, but nothing really too crazy to put this over the edge for me.

Story – A This is where the worry came in for the Pixar heads, because the first three were so satisfying we did not want them ruined. This felt very natural though and did not have to retread anything from the past. It gave us a true ending to Woody's journey and at the end of the day this was always his story. I loved how they brought back Bo Peep, and the arc of the villain Gabby Gabby as well. As always Pixar comes through when they need to.

*A couple other tidbits

- Bonnie kind of stinks compared to Andy, There I said it.

- Jeff Garlin had like two amazing moments in this as well which always puts a smile on my face.

We may have been a tad worried going in, but as always Pixar knocked this one out of the park. Another incredible story about the Toys and another notch in their unrivaled filmography.

A closing chapter to the previous closing chapter. Toy story 4 brings all the charms that make this franchise so incredible along with a premise that will resonate with older audiences while entertaining the kids. With its lighthearted plot, detailed and gorgeous animation, and tons of laughs, this new entry earns its place on this immaculate film series, even if the plot itself isn't as strong as previous ones. Josh Cooley does an incredible job introducing new characters, bringing others back, and paying tribute to the primary with an ending that's highly emotional and impactful thanks to the journey and situations we have seen this characters go through in other installments. But Toy Story 4 doesn't only succeed for what it follows but also has its deeper topics and enough twists and insight to set itself apart. With all that being said, this is a film that will win everyone's hearts, but primarily the hearts of the fans, while rewarding them with such a beautiful and bittersweet chapter.

I'm a massive Toy Story and Pixar fan since 1995. Toy Story changed how I thought, it's THAT kind of movie for me. And I'd be here all day talking about what I love about Toy Story 1, 2 and I'd be here for a week talking about what I love about Toy Story 3 which is a true masterpiece.

Toy Story 3 was a PERRRRRFECT ending to the story of Woody and Buzz. They faced death together.... and survived. You can't top that for an adventure.... and they sure don't in Toy Story 4.

It's not a bad movie just... it didn't do much for me.

I'll tell you one thing that bugged me when it was over was I could count on one hand the number of times I laughed. Where the hell were the jokes in this movie? That bit where the bunny and the chick hatch their plan... get it... but where they go over how they're gonna steal the antique shop owner's key... is one of the funniest gags in ANY Pixar movie. That was the first laugh for me and it was maybe 50 minutes into the movie. That's not the kind of joke/laugh ratio I like.

Forky... lemme talk about Forky....... Forky sucks ass.

When I saw that character in the trailer I had a feeling that character would be annoying. And he's not annoying it's just... they don't do ANYTHING interesting with him at all. This idea of NEW LIFE and they don't do anything cool with it. It's Frankenstein's monster! The number of directions you can do with the creation of a toy and how they begin life seems infinite and... it felt like they threw all of that away. What a letdown. And they spend the first 20 minutes of the movie with his character, too which sucks.

It's a decent story, in these movies they've managed to do a great job giving us these takes on life for toys. For some toys it's about being owned and loved by a kid and the idea of being lost or abandoned is a hell without end....... unless you're Bo evidently.

Bo is a whole new and great character, living this almost Mad Max in the wasteland existence driving around in a skunk car.... long story that's never explained. And I don't wanna give away where the story goes but they make that an option for some of our characters and it's an interesting place to take the story..... but I've seen WAY more interesting stuff happen in these movies.

I think the biggest problem this movie has is Toy Story 3.

Toy Story 3 had everything, a great and HARROWING story, laugh out loud moments every other minute, fantastic new characters, a STELLAR villain in Lotso Huggin' Bear and a climax I don't think Pixar will ever top, frankly.

Not to mention the best opening scene in a Pixar movie with this sort of fantasy that I read as what literally happens for toys when they're played with, they're transported to this other reality where anything is possible. It made Woody's desire to be with Andy make even MORE sense. Who wouldn't want to be a part of adventures like that.

So I was pretty bummed when Toy Story 4 by the time it was over had nothing in common in Toy Story 3. There IS no villain, no Sid, no Stinky Pete, no Lotso, no life or death stakes.... and wow is that a nice way to make me care less about what happens in an adventure story.

And the ending was.... so underwhelming to me. Like infuriatingly underwhelming.

After the pitch perfect The End closure in Toy Story 3, they give us a NEW ending that was so left field and lame to me and sent me out of the theater with a bad taste in my mouth.

And also as a fan of these movies I was crushed that the characters I grew to love like Jessie, Bullseye, Hamm, Potato Head, Rex... aside from Woody, Buzz and Bo the characters I knew were relegated to almost cameos in their own movie. It's like watching an X-Men movie and the only characters that get scenes are Wolverine, Xavier and Jean Grey..... don't gimme all these new characters when we're not done with the old ones yet!

It's not the kind of sequel I hate where it makes the other films worse but based on its own merits... aside from Woody and Bo's story and the quality of the animation this movie did nothing for me.

Never mind the Toy Story movies, after incredible works of art like Inside Out and Coco coming out of Pixar this movie just seemed cookie cutter to me.
