When I first heard they were making a Toy Story 4, I didn't think it was necessary at all. Toy Story 3 ended the story perfectly, what more could be done with it? Not to mention that it's a Pixar sequel made in the 2010s, which don't exactly have a great reputation. Toy Story 3 was great, Cars 2 was bad, Monsters University was okay, Finding Dory was good but forgettable (no pun intended), Cars 3 was okay and Incredibles 2 was a lot of fun but not as memorable as the first movie. It didn't help that none of the Toy Story 4 trailers impressed me. I walked into this movie cautiously optimistic. I hoped it would be at least as good as Incredibles 2 but I was ready for the possibility of a disappointment. However, after seeing the movie, I can confidently say that they did it again. They made another great Toy Story movie. It has an engaging and emotional story, a lovable and memorable cast of characters, interesting themes and ideas, the most beautiful animation that Pixar has put to screen yet, pitch-perfect voice acting, and really great action and comedy! While Toy Story 3 was the perfect ending, I think Toy Story 4 is a great epilogue. This is probably where the story would go next, whether you like it or not. I do have some criticisms though. Some of the writing and comedic timing felt surprisingly clunky and off a couple of times and the ending does feel a little rushed. The ending of Toy Story 3 was definitely a better finale to the series as a whole, it was more epic and larger in scale, but this is more of a finale to the arcs of the main characters. I can't think of a more fitting way to end both this story and the 2010s decade of Pixar movies. It came in with a Toy Story movie and it went out with a Toy Story movie, and it looks like this is the last Pixar sequel we're going to see for a long time. It's been confirmed that there are no sequels coming out for the foreseeable future and they will be putting their focus on original films only. That sounds good to me! Overall, this is a must-see for any fan of the Toy Story movies. It just might be another instant classic. Highly recommended.

Toy Story 4 seems like the type of movie that just shouldn't have worked out. The third film is loved by virtually everyone and the fourth film overrides the ending of the last movie. So, why is Toy Story 4 much better than it should've been? Well, before we get to that, let's discuss the obvious problems: Bonnie and the lack of development of old characters. The former has been the butt of jokes on the Internet thanks to her visible neglect of Woody. While this does cheapen the impact of the ending of the last movie, she's still only a 5-year-old girl and neglecting that one toy is normal behaviour for children her age. So calm down, guys. And with regards as to why the toys spend most of the movie literally and metaphorically in the back seat, I think the shorts and TV specials did help the characters go through arcs. That is, if those are even canon anyway. And they weren't completely useless nor were they interchangeable. Now that I've played the devil's advocate to the two things people have complained about, let's get down to talking about why this movie is good. The animation (uh-doy!). At times, you'd swear Pixar was just showing off, especially compared to how outdated the '90s movies look (mostly the first film, but the second film has its more awkward moments despite having much better human designs and outside scenes). And the script still has its share of emotional and comedic moments, helped by the voice acting. And I do like the new characters and am glad to see how Woody has come a long way from being the guy who'd resort to pushing Buzz under a table, out of Andy's line of sight, just so that he can get to go to Pizza Planet. I do find the ending a worthy end to Woody's story, especially considering the override. Still less esoteric than the one from Wreck-it Ralph 2, if you ask me. I enjoyed Toy Story 4 and consider it a worthy, and presumable ACTUAL, conclusion to not just the series but Pixar's "sequel phase" given that they have no sequels planned for the next decade...at the time I'm writing this review anyway. I just hope that they'll be able to handle the responsibility of making 2 original movies in 2020 without John Lasseter. Though Soul does have Pete Docter directing it, so I wouldn't be too concerned. Only time will tell if they'll gain "Inside Out" levels of acclaim.

Woody is back and about to go on a road trip with his new owner Bonnie and her new favourite toy ‘Forky' a toy she made herself on her first day at nursery.
Woody takes it upon himself to play ‘Dad' to Forky who considers himself to be nothing but trash and throws himself in a bin at every opportunity.  When Forky escapes Woody goes after him and is re-united with Bo-Peep as well as having to watch out for a pull-string doll named Gaby Gaby who wants his voice box as hers is broken. 
The ensuing adventure is just as much fun as the previous Toy Story films and is laden with comedy, classic film references and wonderful animation.
As well as making audiences laugh, Pixar are masters at pulling heart strings,with some very emotional moments and the ending is particularly bittersweet. Toy Story 4 is a wonderful ending to the exceptionally brilliant Toy Story saga.

If you never knew what Toy Story was, then it is a great film. However, after growing up with Toy Story I was a little disappointed that this is how it ended - I wanted more Woody and Buzz rather than new characters that never really needed to be there. Jessie didn't get the screen time she deserved, nor did the rest of the original gang.

Nevertheless, I enjoyed it - but if I ever need my Toy Story fix, I won't be reaching for this one, I will going straight for Toy Story 1 ‘and [not] beyond'.
Great addition to such an iconic series that changed animated films.

I want to start this off by saying that I am a huge Pixar fanboy but I was skeptical about the notion of making another Toy Story after the way Toy Story 3 left the series. Plus adding on to another already stellar trilogy is cause for concern. Now, sitting here writing this, I believe this is my favorite out of the four. The animation is the best in Pixar's relatively short history and the writing is almost as good. For some reason they left buzz on the back burner. Woody once again is sent through a life changing struggle that ultimately ends in a way I felt Toy Story 3 could have gone. However, the best character of the entire film is Forky, an innocent but thought provoking spork that just wanted to be trash. Once again, Pixar perfected what Disney was could not to do (looking at you olaf).

The Joker is a 2019 Drama/Thriller featuring the talents of Joaquin Phoenix and co. I personally really enjoyed this movie. From the amazing cinematography to the Oscar-worthy Score, this movie is one of the best to come out this year. Joaquin Phoenix's performance is one of the most mesmerizing performances I've ever seen on screen, the way he depicts his character is not realistic, but also deeply dark and disturbing to viewers. This man is able to creep out and disturb the audience just by laughing. No music or special effects needed. The plot, though flawed and at times unrealistic, is very, very dark and disturbing. I wouldn't recommend this movie to young audiences. To everyone else, though, this is a must-watch to not only become aware of many difficulties of the mentally ill, as well as why horrible things like what happens in this movie happens in real life.

Just when you think a beloved story has reached the end, completed with a perfectly polishing bookend, there is surprisingly another chapter that takes it further; although questioned whether it is necessary and will it take it further to a new impactful direction – only if it still can be impactful if the franchise is not tired yet. The groundbreaking original "Toy Story" explored the relationship between inanimate object and children, only to discover the former, in plural, that the toys are alive with accustomed feelings that fuels loyalty and the need to be played with. The sentimental resonance is expressed in different ways after each chapter, including the shorts, and the supposedly concluding chapter "Toy Story 4" justified the further continuation with the emotional meaningfulness still ever intact for a more solidifying finale.

Ever since being donated to Bonnie, Andy's former childhood toys are much happier from livelier playtime with the little girl. Woody's rebooted bond with a new kid is instant as he always believes that a toy is always there for the kid, which led him to witness Bonnie's newly-created, crafted toy Forky capturing her young imaginative eyes, but the self-proclaimed trash declared otherwise when refused to be played as a toy. As the family went on a road trip with Bonnie taking the whole gang, it is up to Woody to show Forky the important role he now plays and why he should embrace the new status, but gets soon sidetracked into reuniting with his long-lost friend Bo Peep whose life on the road made her more daring and provides a new insight that will open Woody's eyes.

After how the predecessor ended in remarkable perfection, a continuation would be met with initial doubt. Besides the treated bonus shorts released over the years afterwards in delivering more into the beloved characters' new life, a feature would need to be the final thread to the thematic core. Albeit feeling the somewhat little muddling narrative that fourth chapters tend to pace with in comparison to the previous entries and following up the best, the writing team managed to form ideas and wholesomely delivered, as well in particularly further expressing the relationship between a child and a toy from building to [fully] losing one and a toy finding its purpose. After this film, it has pretty much covered everything over the subject across the span of four films.

Like each film being a toy line's latest series, it welcomes new likable characters that fits into the already-existing assortment, adding additional energy to the original. Joining the gang is Forky with Tony Hale providing much comic relief to the toying definition as well searching for the purpose with uncertain acceptance. Then around Bo Peep's clan is Giggle McDimples vocally lend by Ally Miki, Duke Caboom being another reviving brick for Keanu Reeves' stardom, hanging duo Ducky and Bunny channeling "Key & Peele" antics nicely for predicted amusement, and collecting dust in an antique store is Christina Hendricks' Gabby Gabby with a sympathetic depth. The new characters and additional cast easily becomes part of the series' fun soulfulness that the original cast been building from their in-synced charismatic performances since the beginning, which is in another way of looking at their efforts is functioning the heart and resonating emotional value while providing clever humor.

Now this film would have been rated at four stars for the series' new low considering some decisive turns that could have been better polished than being utterly nonsensical, even if they were sources for needed plot motivation in order to reach the destined point, but "Toy Story 4" again marks how much computer-generated animation has technologically evolved as seen in detailed glaring reflection and facial expressions being more stretched out. It fuels the emotional range by diegetic perspective, which is where the tears started being drawn near the end for an unexpected game-changing decision for one character's truly epic journey. Imperfectly heightened to only be ranked the second best, and furthermore not at the same level nor greatly praised as "The Hidden World" being this year's top contender for Best Animated Feature over this one, it is nonetheless a solid chapter under final narrative assumption with justified continuation and ever loving heart to be another Pixar masterpiece – in honor to their groundbreaking achievement that has reached infinity and beyond. (That probably sounded corny). (A)

The worst Toy Story movie to date.
I don't know how to feel, maybe this movie just wasn't for me. I mean, I am a 22 year old man at this point but that shouldn't really matter.
The previous movies have character and a plot that makes sense. This movie was just all over the place. We can start with the pacing, it was all over the place. The movie went from a slow moving plot to a montage in moments. It didn't feel coherent at all.
The characters that we have gotten to know through three whole movies where no where to be seen. I mean we barely got any time with Buzz Lightyear or Jessie or any of the rest of the gang.
Instead we got a story about Woody still being sour about not being the favorite toy anymore (the plot of the first Toy Story anyone?) and how he finds his purpose in getting his kid to be happy behind the scenes.
And the ending, I mean in what world would Woody leave the gang after 20+ years together just to be with one other toy? The whole plot of the other movies are that what matters most is friendship and being loyal? What happened to that.
Nonsensical plot, weird pacing and most of all it destroyed the great story that the three previous movies had built up over the course of two decades.

Woody and Buzz are off an another adventure with Bonnie, and her new friend Forky. Forky is such a funny and lovable character, and his existential crisis is a very relatable feeling. The ending is beautiful and bittersweet. It's a must see for sure.

Here comes the 4th Toy Story. Woody and Buzz and the gang are back on an adventure, but instead of Buzz rescuing Woody, it's Woody rescuing a new toy and Buzz going after them. It is basically a rehash of the 2nd Toy Story where Woody meets new toys and makes friends with them. I didn't like them adding a female star to the film aka Bo. It seems like a lot of movies are doing that these days and isn't really necessary. The new toys Gabby Gabby and  Duke Caboom I liked the most but not so much the 2 stuffed toys Bunny and Ducky. Most of the movie is focused on Woody with Buzz and the gang taking a back seat with not that many scenes. They did endure lots of comedy into this, it seems Pixar films are doing more of that these days. However, this movie lacks a main villain. We had Sid then Al then Loxo the bear, finally we have..... What no one? Gabby Gabby really isn't one so have this movie without one really just opens up the film to have more jokes instead, boo hoo. The ending was not as sad as it was in Toy Story 3, but it leaves you hanging a bit. Maybe there might be another Toy Story down the road, but I really doubt that. I'd recommend you see this Pixar film. It is still very good for a kids movie with lots of jokes and entertaining stuff throughout, especially with Keanu Reeves playing Duke Caboom.

The themes of the Toy Story films are becoming more and more mature. I guess the creators know that the kids who saw the first Toy Story back in 1995 are now almost in their thirties. It's a pity that the good ol' toys (except for Woody and Bo) didn't have much screentime, though. Not even Buzz.

I watched this movie at the local cinema in Rome, NY. I expected the movie to be really bad after the fantastic ending of Toy Story 3, but it didnt suck as bad as i expected. The animation is fantastic, and is almost photorealistic. However, the story felt lazy to me. The themes of the film contradict eachother. Bo Peep says that having no kid is great and that toys without a kid have a certain freedom. After giving woody a speech about this, Bo Peep helps the doll find a child, and claims that that is the better thing. So what is the theme? That a toy should be loyal to a child or that a toy should fuck their child over and be free? Very confusing. The new characters are either really stupid or not funny at all, and the old characters didnt get shit from pixar. They sat in the r.v. and tricked some grown ass men into thinking that the gps was broken. HOWEVER, the ending saved this movie from 2 stars. The ending was emotional due to great performances by Tim Allen and Tom Hanks. In conclusion, this is deffinately what would have happened after Toy Story 3, but it was not needed for the universe. It was basically a fairly well done cash grab.

It was disappointing and worst of all forgettable. The plot felt very unpolished compared to Pixar's previous ventures with this franchise and it focused on introducing too many new characters that we had barely any screen time with any of the characters we actually care about. Woody didn't even really feel like Woody in this entry almost like Hanks had stopped caring about the role and/or was given a kind of lousy script. One of the most heartbreaking parts of this entry is that the relationships we really developed in the first two entries were forgotten about. Buzz and Woody had one scene of development together, that's it. I also feel like Buzz got the short end of the stick as far as I feel like they could have written him out of the script and nothing would have been lost as far as the plot is concerned. Jessie (never been my favorite character) also got maybe 2-3 minutes of actual screen time and a sentence or two of script. I can't even remember Bullseye being in the movie. Bonnie's new toys didn't get enough time to actually have much of a personality, the Key and Peele toys weren't that funny (suprisingly) and just cheapened the overall experience. Bo Peep was an annoying character for me. I am all for equality between genders but this just seems so tacked on and politically charged and irked me just like Belle in the live action's Beauty and the Beast or those Frozen girls. She was annoying to watch and had the same personality as every other Disney princess since Disney "woke." The movie's only antagonist's story arch resolved with 20 minutes to go and she was utterly forgettable. Her dummy henchmen are going to be giving my boys nightmares for the rest of their lives and were definitely not something I expected to see in a family movie (and I'm not one to shelter my children from potentially scary scenes, looking at you shark attack in Finding Nemo). I'm surprised how high this has been rated and just don't see it. For me it ranks right around Monster's University on the Pixar lineup with Cars 2 (never saw 3) being one of the few below it. I even liked Finding Dory significantly more than this one and that was the movie that made me realize that Pixar has lost it's magic. If it weren't for Inside Out I probably wouldn't bother seeing any more of Pixar (or Disney for that matter) until they make some big changes.

This was the first Toy Story that left me with a humdrum feeling inside. I knew the underlying lesson was rich, the animation gorgeous and the story was full of excitement/adventure. It’s just...the franchise has become tiresome.

SPOILERS:
If I was a feminist I would've loved this movie. Unfortunately I still haven't quite been swayed by the latest feminist agenda popping up in movies and TV in recent years. Toy Story 4 tried hard and there was plenty of good moments and narrative absent of any agenda that made the film enjoyable. But the feminist moments just left a bad taste in my mouth. Woody is demeaned to the point of an "accessory" by Bo Peep, and yet we're expected to believe that Woody would love Bo Peep and just leave all his old friends behind who he's been with for all the three previous movies. It almost encourages masochism and low self esteem. It just feels spiteful and wrong. And then the passing of the sheriff's badge from Woody to Jessie just felt like a nod to the passing of the patriarchy to the matriarchy, which, again, if I were a feminist I'd have loved that moment. But to me it feels forced and politically motivated and I prefer art to be honest and reflect reality, rather than try to force fit an agenda onto a narrative in the hopes of recreating reality. It basically turns art into propaganda. But besides those moments, the rest of the movie was pretty good.

Toy Story 4 was average at best. As someone whose first ever film was the original story and someone who saw Toy Story 3 in cinemas just before I started university (watching Andy head off for college), I consider myself very much of the Toy Story generation. This film really feels like it's forgotten it's older fans and has moved on to a much younger audience, which is quite sad. It lacked the usual charm of a Pixar movie that sees jokes for both children and adults. Scenes are repetitive and cover a lot of the same information multiple times. 

The toy cast list has almost been tripled and yet next to no time is spent with any character that isn't Woody or Bo. Even staple characters like Buzz and Jessie are very much sidelined. So many characters are introduced and given next to no screen time.

It's sad to see Toy Story end this way after, what I consider, a perfect ending to their third instalment.

I'll be honest; when I heard that pixar was making yet another Toy Story Movie, I groaned. I believed that the third installment had a perfect ending and that there wasn't a need for a fourth entry. Boy was I wrong. The movie itself is animated beautifully, everything was crisp and gorgeous to look at. And the story? Well, it's just as amazing as the animation. The movie mostly centers around woody and bo-peep; you don't really get to see the other toys all that much. And to be honest, I'm fine with that. Pixar didn't throw the conclusion of the third movie out, rather, they continued woody's story because his character arc was not yet finished. The other toys... their stories really did end in Toy Story Three, which is why this movie focuses on woody rather than all of the other toys. Overall, I loved this movie and cried my eyes out at the end. This is truly pixar at it's finest.

You already knew this film was going to rock. It just kept box ticking the whole way through. We get to see Andy again, there's that beautiful transition sequence that Pixar excel at to bring us up to present events and we're back with the gang pretty much where we left off.

So about half hour in I started to wonder about the old characters, the Potato heads seemed mute (I know Ron died but they said they had his dialogue covered, but 3 lines?) Even Rex was unusually quiet and unpanicked. However the new characters seamlessly replaced them and I wasn't left wondering anymore. I loved the introduction of the little cop and then the inevitable dark side in the form of the ventriloquist dummies and the creepy but pretty little talking doll. The stunt guy was a great addition and each of the new guys played a nice part in the overall story telling, not forgetting the 2 stuffed toys from the shooting range. The little alternate reality scenes with them were a genius idea and added yet another layer to the already bulging amount of depth to this film.

The animation was on another level and the realism, although held a bit in check I feel so as to not go full on photo realistic was really lovely and made the whole thing sit as a believable film a whole lot more. I loved the way that although there was this dark threat to the film that is was actually done in a really nice way and the threat was neutralised and weaved itself perfectly into the story and the antagonist became the climax of the film. Before I went in I was wondering when they were going to deliver the emotional punch in the guts and as per the previous film it was almost at the end. I thought I could avoid it, not be affected, or just brush it off somehow but damn, those guys did it again and had me crying in the cinema when the little lost girl picked Dolly up and hugged her. Crikey, these guys know how to deliver that so masterfully and pull all of the invested emotion into a simple scene, leaving you brimming with all sorts of feelings and the unstoppable moist eyes.

So yeah, we went full circle, we learned all about friendships all over again, we had Buzz on another tangent with his inner voice and overall many layers of adult themes crammed into a children's romp. But Pixar know their quarry, these guys are the masters and they can pick and choose the top talent in the world to come and work for them. I noticed the film was directed by an unfamiliar face but clearly the old guard had a huge influence on this movie. I loved it from start to finish, what a feast, what a way to go out, belly laughs, tears and I just can't wait to watch it over and over again like I do with all of Pixar's masterpieces. Simply fantastic!

Widely dubbed as one of cinemas all-time greatest trilogies, Toy Story was an unblemished set of films, never misplacing a step, and while the surprise 4th rendition isn't quite that level of excellence, it's still as charming and heartwarming as ever.

The gang that we grew to love is still very much together, under their new ‘kid' Bonnie. Woody our ever present source of righteousness finds himself struggling to come to terms with no longer being the beloved favourite. Something's never change though, as Woody remains the kindest and loyalist toy you would ever want. He goes the extra mile to ensure that Bonnie doesn't get down in the dumps with her kindergarten blues. This leads to the introduction of our newest member, the surprising engaging ‘Forky'. Several events follow until we end up riding that old movie trope, The Road Trip. 

Slow to get going, the story gets stuck in a loop. It's not till the end where you see the Toy Story you love begin to flourish and blossom, making you feel all those emotions this franchise has made you ever so familiar with. 
Repetition runs rife, woven into the fabric of the narrative. The repetition begins and ends with Forky, the newest member of our toy chest. Suffering from a crisis of identity and belonging Forky seeks refuge in the place he believes he belongs. Thankfully this source of personal irritation is lulled by a tender scene, ran by Woody.

While it may start slow, the opening sequence is quintessential Pixar, a delightful recap (that I was more than grateful for), brimming with warmth and emotion, just lovely storytelling. Quickly catching you up on Bo Peep's initial exit, before her return as a kick-ass, wandering renegade, seeking a life of freedom, which opposes the standard Toy life. 

As for the new characters, they're all good, and there's a few I would've liked to see more of - and had their backstory improved upon. Gabby is a refreshing antagonist for a film targeted towards kids. She operates in the grey area of ‘villains', she is without a doubt an intimidating on-screen presence, but the lines are blurred between good and evil, which is pleasing to see. The other side characters are all good, standouts being Duke Caboom and Bunny and Ducky. Ultimately they're sacrificed as Woody takes centre stage. He dominates the screen time, gobbling it all up. 

I do feel I should acknowledge that this 4th tale of the toys hits on similar beats covered in the first three tales. There is a distinct similarity in how the plot and character actions are bent to progress the story. At times it may feel contrived, but that feeling will be over-run by sheer nostalgia and joy that will never leave these characters.

In Toy Story 3 we all felt like the story had ran its course, and finished perfectly, but we were wrong, Toy Story was finished, but Woody's Story still had legs in it yet, and I'm pleased to say that this 4th installment did a wonderful job of telling and closing his arc, that meant so much to so many.

The movie was great, although, I agree, it wasn't needed. Even though the last movie In the franchise wrapped things up perfectly, with Woody and the rest of Andy's toys now belonging to Bonnie, it was nice to see what happened to the toys after the last film. The movie opens up with a flashback to nine years ago, back at Andy's house, where Woody and Bo Peep are being separated as Bo Peep gets sent away due to Molly (Andy's sister) going to college. We then cut back to present day where Bonnie starts her first day at kindergarten and she creates a new toy out of a plastic spork and some crafting materials, which she names her new toy "Forky". Forky, who Bonnie takes home, does not believe he is a toy and insists he is "trash". It is then that Bonnie and her parents go on a road trip, and Bonnie brings along her toys, including "Forky". Forky, still believing he is trash, jumps out of a window and Woody goes to find him. Woody then finds Forky and convinces him he is a toy (or, at least, "Bonnie's 'trash'".) Woody and Forky then join back up with the rest of the toys, but not before stumbling upon an old antique store, which Woody thinks Bo Peep is inside. Woody, and, by extension, Forky, then go inside to try and find Bo Peep, but do not find her. Instead, they find a new character named "Gabby Gabby" who says she knows Bo Peep and offers to take them to her. It is then that "Gabby Gabby" plans to take Woody's "voice box" as hers is defective. Woody then bolts out of there, but not before Forky is captured. Woody then wants to head back in and save Forky, knowing that Bonnie needs him, but ends up finding Bo Peep, who is roaming on her own. Woody then tells Bo Peep that he needs to get Forky back from the antique store, where he's being held captive there, but Bo initially refuses, saying she used to be there but was tired of "sitting on a shelf", not being bought by someone. They, eventually, end up going to save him. We then cut back to the other toys, who are in the RV, and Buzz is getting worried about Woody for being gone too long. He ends up trying to find him, but gets mistaken for a carnival toy. He tries to break free, but not before meeting two more stuffed carnival toys, being "Bunny" and "Ducky", who hate him for taking "top prize" at the carnival game. He then breaks free and sets off to find Woody, with "Bunny" and "Ducky" following behind, as they aren't done giving him "a piece of their mind". Buzz eventually finds Woody, and, by extension, Bo Peep, with "Bunny" and "Ducky" catching up to Buzz and beating him up. Woody then promises them he can take them to Bonnie to be played with (spoiler alert: he never does) and they get excited. The team then go out to find Forky, who they do eventually find, but not before Gabby Gabby tries to take Woody's "voice box". Woody, begrudgingly, lets her have it if it meant Forky would be set free, and she agrees. Gabby Gabby, with her "voice box" fixed, then tries to get a kid to take her home, but, ultimately, gets rejected. Woody then offers to take Gabby Gabby to Bonnie to be played with (which, again, he doesn't do.) Instead, Gabby Gabby sees a lost kid at the carnival and, knowing how she's a "lost toy", decides to cheer her up by being taken home by her. Woody then finally meets up with the rest of the toys, Bo Peep and Forky with him, but then decides to stay with Bo Peep as he wants to help other toys get played with. I really am not a fan of this ending. Yes, Woody found his "true calling", but he, not to mention "Bo" and the other new toys he met along the way, could have easily stayed with Bonnie to be played with, but, I guess "Pixar" just wanted another "feel-good" ending. Speaking of which, before the movie came out, I initially heard it was gonna be darker and more "heart-wrenching" than the last movie, so I went in to this movie expecting a "tear-jerker" similar to the "incinerator" scene from the last film, but I didn't get that. Yes, it was "warm-and-fuzzy", but it didn't "move" me. Maybe this is because I'm getting used to these kinds of movies. Overall, the film was good and I highly recommend you check it out.

Woody and the gang embark on one last adventure in Toy Story 4.  While on a road trip with her parents Bonnie losses her new favorite toy that she made in preschool and Woody attempts to get him back, and along the way he reunites with Bo Peep, who's joined a traveling carnival.  Most of the original cast returns along with several new additions, including Christina Hendricks, Tony Hale, and Keanu Reeves.  Once again the series takes on some very poignant themes, but it isn't quite as nuanced as in previous films and comes off as kind of talky and heavy handed.  The lack of a strong villain is also problematic.  However, the comedy is incredibly well-done and delivers a lot of laughs.  But it also has a lot of heart.  Though it's not as strong as some of the other entries in the franchise, Toy Story 4 is a fun and heartwarming family film.

This movie was crafted exceptionally well, we join our old friends Woody, Buzz, Bo Peep, and all the others... Including Mr Potato Head, still voiced by Don Rickles, two years after his death. 25 years after the original films release, this film still has the ability to captivate audiences of all ages. We find our selves, once again following woody on an adventure, that spirals in to a chaotic turn of events. As we have come to expect from the franchise. The script is very well written with a lot of first time comedic value. Especially the dialogue between Woody, and his newly found friend Forky. A talking spork. You can also expect some moments of great sadness, as this seems to be the last time all of our friends will be together. With all that said this movie will stand the test of time, and is definitely worth a watch, or 2, or 3, or 4.

People didn't want a toy story 4 as it would ruined the way that toy story 3 ended, but it didn't at all. This isn't a "Andy" film, this one is focusing on Bonnie growing up with the toys and also showing us that Woody needs to move on from being Andy's favourite toy. Yes this film moves away from focusing on the main set of toys to focus on the brand new set of characters, but that's where the humour comes from and this is definitely the funniest toy story movie and its down to the new characters, the main stand out is Forky, the chemistry with him and Woody is 2 stand out performances inside this film. The main villain, Gabby Gabby is probably the most complex villain in the franchise, but I don't think she is the greatest villain, but still great to watch. Bringing back Bo Peep into the fold really helps to bring Woody's arc to a wonderful and emotional ending. However I do not think this is the most emotional toy story film as that belongs to toy story 3, but it's still emotional to see what happens at the end of the film, especially the final words that Woody and Buzz share together. That door has closed, or has it?????

Toy Story 3 wrapped up on a seemingly conclusive note. That all changed when Toy Story 4 was announced. Upon learning of a fourth sequel, I was unsurprised and disappointed at Disney's seemingly endless level of corporate greed.

Cynicism aside, I was pleasantly surprised (to an extent). Toy Story 4 manages to retain the charm and whimsy of the earlier films and isn't a total soulless cash-grab. I actually liked the themes it explored as well as the new characters - Forky's existential crises and Key/Peele's arguing were both quite enjoyable. This was a good, not amazing, Toy Story film that is likely to leave fans of the franchise or just fans of Pixar in general pleased.

I saw "Toy Story 1" but aside from remembering some of the characters I remember little of the story. I skipped 2 & 3 but not having anything else to see today I decided to see the, supposedly, latest and last story. It is a story about how one feels not being wanted or loved anymore and how to handle the feelings and life changes.

In this film we find an old friend Woody, a sheriff, has lost his first owner, Andy, who pushed him aside when Andy went off to college. Woody found consolation with Bonnie who inherited him but now she is off to kindergarten and has made her own toy, Forky, made from trash items like pipe cleaners, a plastic spoon, doll's eyes and considers himself trash but Bonnie loves him. Very shortly after bringing him home she loses him and Woody feels it is his duty to return Forky, now Bonnie's friend who in turn deserts him while at the same time convince Forky he is not just trash.

The chase involves some old, and many new characters, in the Toy Story series but bogs down in the chase sequences while at the same time offering a few laughs such as a skunk sort of being a Trojan horse or at least camouflage! The main tug at the emotional strings are the reunion of Bo Peep and Woody with the former having accepted the fact that she no longer serves a purpose just moving here and there.

Not having seen the middle stories I am not sure who is new here but Tom Hanks, as always, is very effective and, yes, believable as Woody. Tony Hale, new as Forky, is funny while Tim Allen as Buzz Lightyear gives solid backup to his friends while Annie Potts returns as Bo Peep as a very strong woman and Christina Hendricks as sort of a villainous Gabby Gabby who wants Woody's voice box. One of the newest characters, and definitely the funniest, is Keanu Reeves as Duke Caboom, a Canadian stunt motorcyclist, full of himself and daring to do anything.

"Toy Story 4" is a film for both children of all ages and adults will, in many cases, enjoy it more! After seeing about a dozen of the 'new' ways films are animated I am still intrigued at how the characters seem alive and, in many cases, you believe in them.

I was initially sceptical about this film, and knowing what went on in production didn't help, so I went into it expecting to be at least a bit disappointed. Then I came out the cinema with a big smile on my face because I was so happy it was made. The animation is the most beautiful I've ever seen both inside and outside of Pixar, it's emotionally deep and complex with funny moments, heartwarming moments, nostalgia, anger, and the bittersweet ending, and while Toy Story 3 was the perfect ending for the franchise, I consider Toy Story 4 to be the perfect ending for Woody. Seeing all these characters back on the big screen was a delight, and all the new characters are everything between hilarious and terrifying with a fantastic villain that from a film making viewpoint is better than Lotso. The only big issue I have with it is that many of the old characters are put to the side, and I can see lovers of Buzz being extremely disappointed in how the film handled him. Still, it was completely necessary, and I admire Pixar for achieving the impossible.

There is this very irritating feeling when you watch a movie that everyone praised to infinity and beyond, and then you realize that you are among the very few that found it to be not great at all. Toy Story 4 is one such movie for me. Yes, some conversations are pretty good, the photorealistic animation is great and the film has its fine moments for sure, but overall the script is just rehashed in dialogue and themes from all of the previous movies. It's a very lazy, very unnecessary movie given the greatness of ‘Toy Story 3' and its finale. The humor is fine, but rare, and its action/adventure elements are overwhelming and very uninteresting. And I love Pixar to death, but this particular franchise is the most overrated thing they've ever produced, and this film specifically is their worst after ‘Cars 2'. That's why I find it very frustrating when critics show bias toward a certain franchise and heap praise when in reality this is just a weak movie when watched with objective, unbiased eyes.

Although none of the sequels have quite matched the originality of the first Toy Story, this is a sweet film and its fun spending time with old friends.  Weve definitely seen some of the tropes before - toys in peril, Woodys obsession with being there for his kid no matter the cost  even when hes being overlooked in favor of another toy. But there are genuine laugh-out-loud and reach-for-tissue moments, and a genuinely surprising ending that felt right. I dont know if its the end of this series, but it feels like a good place to say farewell to the characters.

When Toy Story 4 was first announced, I was really confused and mad. This franchise already had an amazing trilogy that ended on a tear jerking and epic note, that needed no sequel. But Toy Story 4 delivered giving a amazing story and showing us just how far someone will go for another persons' happiness. This movie by no means lives up to either the original Toy Story or Toy Story 2 (which are my favorites), but it is still an amazing film.
With emotion, beautiful animation, and a story definitely worth while, "Toy Story 4" manages to overcome expectations and deliver a really solid film (mostly).
